head.title: The End? The Fall of the House of Poe

hedline.hl1: The End? The Fall of the House of Poe

abstract.p: Charles Cantalupo letter criticizes New York University's attitude in planning demolition of Edgar Allan Poe house

block.p: You report that John H. Beckman, a New York University spokesman, said, ''The Telltale Heart does not beat beneath the floorboards of this building,'' in response to the State Supreme Court's ruling that the university can raze the building that was Edgar Allan Poe's only long-term Manhattan residence (news article, Oct. 4).
Mr. Beckman confuses fact with fiction and prose with poetry.

You report that John H. Beckman, a New York University spokesman, said, ''The Telltale Heart does not beat beneath the floorboards of this building,'' in response to the State Supreme Court's ruling that the university can raze the building that was Edgar Allan Poe's only long-term Manhattan residence (news article, Oct. 4).
Mr. Beckman confuses fact with fiction and prose with poetry.
While Poe lived in Manhattan, he bathed in his new-found literary fame and was relatively free of the inner demons that ruined most of the rest of his life.
Thanks to New York University, the prophecy of Poe's poem ''The Raven'' can now be extended to include the last, tangible remnant in Manhattan of this great American writer's life: ''Nevermore.''
